children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Read n and b.

read *, n, b

! Allocate arrays. allocate(q(n), ans(n))

head =1

tail=0 

! Main loop. do i=1,n

    read *, t, d

    ! remove from front as long as first element <= t

    ! first, check while head<=tail AND q(head) < =t:

    do while( head <= tail .and. q(head) <= t ) head = head +1

    end do

    ! check if the current size after this <= b.

    current_q_size = tail - head +1  ! yes, (tail - head +1) if ( current_q_size <= b ) then

        if ( current_q_size ==0 ) then

            ! queue empty, previous is -1, so t +d.

            ans(i) = t +d

        else

            ans(i) = q( tail ) +d

        endif

        ! add to queue. tail = tail +1

        q(tail) = ans(i)

    else 

        ans(i) = -1

    end if

end do

! Output results

do i=1,n

    write(*, '(I0,X)', advance='no') ans(i)

end do

write(*,*)  ! new line.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
deallocate(q, ans)

end program

Now, in Fortran, the write statement for the answer must print space separated numbers, with a trailing space, but the problem might expect a space at the end. The loop can be written as:

do i = 1, n

    write (unit=*, fmt='(I0, 1X)', advance='no') ans(i)

end do

write(*,*)  

That way, after the first loop, each number is written with a space, and the final write ends the line.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Alternatively, use 'advance' to keep on the same line.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:

write(*,'(100000(I0,1X))') ans(1:n) But that might not be better. Alternatively, see that in the code, after the loop is done, you can:

do i =1,n

    print *, ans(i)

end do

But that would print each on separate lines. So the proper way is to print all in a single line with spaces between.

program codeforces_644_B

  implicit none

  integer :: n, b, i, head, tail
  integer(8), allocatable :: ans(:), q(:)
  integer(8) :: t, d, current_q_size

  !

Wait this should be the correct fortran code. Now check some syntax details. - The 'do while' loops in Fortran can be written as:

do while (condition)

  ...

end do
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: - The read statement uses 'read(*,*)', which is fine.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: - The writing: in the do loop over i from 1 to n for the output, each element is written with 'I0' and '1X' spacing. '
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: I0' prints the number without leading spaces, but in some cases maybe using '(g0)' but I0 is okay for integers. The advance='no' keeps the output on the same line.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: - The final 'write(*, *)' prints a new line. Wait the trailing space is preserved because the last element is printed with a space. The judge might accept it.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: In Java code, the original code also does System.out.print(ans[i] + " "), which adds a space at the end. So the Fortran code would do the same. Yes.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Thus, this should be the correct translation.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Read n and b
  read(*,*) n, b

  ! Allocate arrays
  allocate(q(n), ans(n))

  head = 1
  tail = 0

  do i = 1, n
    read(*,*) t, d

    ! Remove elements from front until the first element > t
    do while (head <= tail .and. q(head) <= t)
      head = head + 1
    end do

    ! Compute current queue size
    current_q_size = tail - head + 1

    if (current_q_size <= b) then
      ! Can add the current element to the queue
      if (current_q_size == 0) then
        ans(i) = t + d
      else
        ans(i) = q(tail) + d
      end if
      ! Add to queue
      tail = tail + 1
      q(tail) = ans(i)
    else
      ans(i) = -1
    end if
  end do

  ! Print results with space separation
  do i = 1, n
    write(*, "(I0, 1X)", advance='no') ans(i)
  end do
  write(*, *)  !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:

Thus the fortran code would be as given above:

Here's the code:

program codeforces_644_B

  implicit none

  integer :: n, b, i, head, tail
  integer(8), allocatable :: ans(:), q(:)
  integer(8) :: t, d, current_q_size

  ! Read n and b
  read(*,*) n, b

  ! Allocate arrays
  allocate(q(n), ans(n))

  head = 1
  tail = 0

  do i = 1, n
    read(*,*) t, d

    ! Remove elements from front until the first element > t
    do while (head <= tail .and. q(head) <= t)
      head = head + 1
    end do

    ! Compute current queue size
    current_q_size = tail - head + 1

    if (current_q_size <= b) then
      ! Can add the current element to the queue
      if (current_q_size == 0) then
        ans(i) = t + d
      else
        ans(i) = q(tail) + d
      end if
      ! Add to queue
      tail = tail + 1
      q(tail) = ans(i)
    else
      ans(i) = -1
    end if
  end do

  ! Print results with space separation
  do i = 1, n
    write(*, "(I0, 1X)", advance='no') ans(i)
  end do
  write(*, *)  ! Add a newline at the end
  deallocate(q, ans)

end program

- The writing: in the do loop over i from 1 to n for the output, each element is written with 'I0' and '1X' spacing. 'I0' prints the number without leading spaces, but in some cases maybe using '(g0)' but I0 is okay for integers. The advance='no' keeps the output on the same line.

- The final 'write(*, *)' prints a new line.
